etymologies: Middle English; earliest use found in Arms. From Anglo-Norman purprin, purperin and Old French, Middle French purprin (French (now rare) pourprin; also (after classical Latin purpura) Old French purpurayn, Middle French, French purpurin) of a purple colour, purplish, also in heraldic use from purper, purpre + -in

definitions: Of a purple colour or tinge, purplish; †(Heraldry) = "purpure" (obsolete).
